blocks.text: What is CSS?

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) controls the **look and feel** of your HTML.

You write rules like `selector { property: value; }` to change colors, spacing, layout, and animations.

CSS “cascades”: the final style depends on specificity, order, and inheritance.
Tip: Try changing the values in the example (numbers, colors, text) and re-run. Learning happens by experimenting.
CSS controls presentation: colors, spacing, fonts, and layout.

blocks.text: How to include CSS

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
To use CSS, you can:

• Add it **inline** (`style="..."`)
• Use **internal CSS** inside `<style>` in the `<head>`
• Use an **external stylesheet** with `<link rel="stylesheet" href="...">` (best for real websites).
Tip: Try changing the values in the example (numbers, colors, text) and re-run. Learning happens by experimenting.
Best practice: keep CSS in external files and link them in the head.

blocks.text: Selectors

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
CSS selectors are used to target HTML elements to apply styles.

Common types include:
- Element selector (h1, p)
- Class selector (.box)
- ID selector (#header)
- Attribute selector ([type="text"])
- Pseudo-class (:hover)

Selectors are the foundation of styling in CSS.
Tip: Try changing the values in the example (numbers, colors, text) and re-run. Learning happens by experimenting.
Target elements: element, class, id, attribute, pseudo-class, pseudo-element.

blocks.text: Specificity

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Specificity determines which CSS rule is applied when multiple rules target the same element.

Priority order:
- Inline styles
- ID selectors
- Class, attribute, pseudo-class
- Element selectors

If specificity is equal, the last declared rule is applied.
Tip: Try changing the values in the example (numbers, colors, text) and re-run. Learning happens by experimenting.
When multiple rules match, the more specific selector wins. If equal, later wins.

blocks.text: Box Model

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Every element is a rectangle made of:

**Content → Padding → Border → Margin**

Padding adds space *inside* the border, margin adds space *outside* the border.

Understanding the box model helps you size, align, and space elements correctly.
Tip: Try changing the values in the example (numbers, colors, text) and re-run. Learning happens by experimenting.
Content → padding → border → margin.

blocks.text: Flexbox

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Flexbox is a layout system used to arrange elements in a single direction (row or column).

When display:flex is applied to a container, its child elements become flexible items.

You can control layout using:
- justify-content → horizontal alignment
- align-items → vertical alignment
- gap → space between items

Flexbox is widely used for responsive layouts and aligning elements easily.
Tip: Try changing the values in the example (numbers, colors, text) and re-run. Learning happens by experimenting.
Use flex for one-direction layouts (row/column).

blocks.text: CSS Grid

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
CSS Grid is a **2‑dimensional** layout system (rows + columns).

Define a grid on the parent using `display: grid`, then control columns/rows with `grid-template-columns/rows`.

Grid is perfect for page layouts, cards, dashboards, and complex responsive designs.
Tip: Try changing the values in the example (numbers, colors, text) and re-run. Learning happens by experimenting.
Grid for 2D layouts.

blocks.text: CSS Variables

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
CSS variables (custom properties) store reusable values.

Define them in `:root` (global) like `--primary: #2563eb;` then use with `var(--primary)`.

They make themes easier and reduce repeated values.

Custom properties make themes easy.

blocks.text: What is JavaScript?

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
JavaScript is used to make web pages interactive.

It allows you to:
- Handle user events (click, input)
- Modify content dynamically
- Work with data and logic

JavaScript brings functionality and behavior to web pages.
Tip: Try changing the values in the example (numbers, colors, text) and re-run. Learning happens by experimenting.
JavaScript adds behavior: events, DOM updates, storage, and API calls.

blocks.text: SEO & Meta Tags

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Meta tags live in the `<head>` and describe your page.

A good `<title>` and `<meta name="description">` improve SEO and link previews.

Social platforms also use Open Graph/Twitter meta tags when sharing.

blocks.text: Position

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
The `position` property controls how an element is placed.

• `relative`: stays in flow, can offset with top/left.
• `absolute`: removed from flow, positioned inside nearest positioned ancestor.
• `fixed`: relative to viewport.
• `sticky`: switches between relative and fixed while scrolling.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.
Z-index

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
`z-index` controls the stacking order of positioned elements.

Higher values appear on top.

It works only when the element is positioned (`relative/absolute/fixed/sticky`).
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.

blocks.text: Pseudo-classes

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Pseudo-classes target an element **state**.

Examples: `:hover` (mouse over), `:focus` (keyboard focus), `:active` (pressed), `:nth-child()` (position in parent).
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.

blocks.title: Hover preview
blocks.description: Hover the button to see the background change.

blocks.text: Pseudo-elements

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Pseudo-elements create **virtual elements** inside an element.

Use `::before` and `::after` with `content` to add icons, badges, decorative lines, etc.

They are great for UI details without extra HTML.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.

blocks.title: Badge demo
blocks.description: A label with an automatic NEW badge.

blocks.text: Animations

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Animations use `@keyframes` to define steps over time.

Then apply with `animation: name duration timing infinite;`.

Use animations for subtle attention (loading, highlights) — don’t overdo it.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.
Transforms

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Transforms visually move/rotate/scale an element without changing document flow.

They’re fast and smooth, especially with transitions.

Common transforms: `translate`, `scale`, `rotate`.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.
Typography Basics

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Typography settings control readability.

Start with a comfortable `font-size`, use `line-height: 1.5` for paragraphs, and keep weights consistent.

Good typography makes your UI look professional even with simple colors.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.

result.html: Readable text is easier to scan. Use line-height and consistent font sizes.

starter.html: Edit font-size and line-height to see the difference.

blocks.text: Arrays

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Arrays store an ordered list of values.

Use indexes starting at 0. Add items with `push`, remove with `pop`, and loop through with `for` or `forEach`.

Arrays are used everywhere: lists, menus, results, lessons, etc.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.
Objects

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Objects store data as **key → value** pairs.

Use dot notation `obj.key` or bracket notation `obj['key']`.

Objects model real things like a lesson, user, or settings.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.

const lesson = { title:'Box Model', minutes:12 };
console.log(lesson.title);

blocks.text: Array Methods

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
`map`, `filter`, and `find` help you transform arrays.

• `map` → make a new array
• `filter` → keep matching items
• `find` → first matching item

These are perfect for search and navigation features.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.
Fetch API

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
`fetch()` requests data from a URL.

It returns a Promise. You usually convert the response using `json()`.

In real apps, fetch is used to load course content from a backend.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.

blocks.title: Fetch preview
blocks.description: We simulate output by reading local JSON.

blocks.text: Promises

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Promises represent a value you’ll get later (async).

Use `.then()` for success and `.catch()` for errors.

Most modern APIs (fetch, timers, etc.) use Promises.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.
Async/Await

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
`async/await` is syntax on top of Promises.

Mark a function `async`, then `await` a Promise.

This makes code easier to read compared to long `.then()` chains.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.

blocks.title: Async preview
blocks.description: We show how many lessons exist.

starter.js: async function load(){const r=await fetch(url);return r.json();}

blocks.text: Error Handling

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Use `try/catch` to handle runtime errors without breaking the whole app.

This is useful when parsing JSON, accessing storage, or calling APIs.

Always show a friendly message to users instead of crashing.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.
Modules (import/export)

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Modules help you split JavaScript into separate files.

Use `export` to expose functions/values, and `import` to use them elsewhere.

For this project, modules make the code easier to maintain as you add more courses.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.

result.html: Tip: use type="module" in your script tag.

blocks.text: Backgrounds & Gradients

blocks.title: Explanation
blocks.text:
Backgrounds set the surface style of elements.

Use `background-color` for solid color and `background-image: linear-gradient(...)` for gradients.

Keep backgrounds subtle so text stays readable.
Tip: edit the example values and refresh the preview. Learning happens by experimenting.
